cab.content: [This Document is the Property of His Britannic Majesty's Government.)[Printed for the Cabinet. September 1924.) SECRET. JOP. 451 (24).In continuation of CP. 446 (24), I circulate for the information of my colleagues the following private and personal telegrams which have passed between me and the Viceroy.OLIVIER.19th September 1924.Telegram from Viceroy, dated 19t/t September 1924.Private and personal. Bengal Ordinance. We have informed the Bengal Government and, meanwhile, are revising draft to give effect to your views, with which we are in agreement. Unless the Government of Bengal make representations to the contrary, I do not anticipate any serious objection. The terms of your suggested amendment are not quite suitable for technical reasons, but the full sense will be incorporated. I shall be glad if you will now give final approval as action may have to be taken. I assume that you have no objection to Part I. of Ordinance, and that your telegram authorises issue immediately if necessary with the terms to carry out your views. rTelegram from Secretary of State to Viceroy, dated 19th September 1924. Private and personal. Bengal Ordinance. Your telegram of to-day: 1. Very glad to learn your concurrence. Please telegraph precise revised wording proposed in time for Cabinet, Monday-morning. No objection was intended in my telegram to Part I. You have my authority to issue Ordinance as soon as you may deem it absolutely necessary in discharge of your responsibilities to do so, but I should prefer that, if possible, issue should be deferred at least until after Monday's Cabinet and any further telegram from me arising therefrom which I will send that afternoon.2. Are you satisfied as to power of Bengal Legislature by law (as distinct from that of Governor-General, by Ordinance) to suspend habeas corpus jurisdiction of High Court and its power to transfer cases ? See clause 8 of Bengal Government Bill.
